abstract.p: Letter from Eric Cazdyn says now that scientists have deciphered map of human genetic code, they should seek to decipher map of social code

block.p: At this moment of self-congratulation regarding the human genome project (front page, June 27), I feel the need to throw sand on the fire. Instead of deciphering the map of the human genetic code, why not shoot for the map of the social code?
Why not try to find the code for a more effective education system or to eliminate starvation and poverty? Why is such a herculean project not under way?

At this moment of self-congratulation regarding the human genome project (front page, June 27), I feel the need to throw sand on the fire. Instead of deciphering the map of the human genetic code, why not shoot for the map of the social code?
Why not try to find the code for a more effective education system or to eliminate starvation and poverty? Why is such a herculean project not under way?
Is it because the genetic code is a qualitatively easier circle to square? Perhaps. But surely a global effort on social issues on the scale of the genome project would have borne substantial fruit.
Or is it a matter of interests? Discovering the answers to these social problems is not profitable, not encouraged by the logic of capital.
Which leads to the question: What is so profitable and encouraging to capital about the human genome project? And is this something we should gloat about?
